metadata.title: Exposing TiO2 (001) crystal facet in nano Au-TiO2 heterostructures for enhanced photodegradation of methylene blue

Full length article
Exposing TiO2 (001) crystal facet in nano Au-TiO2 heterostructures for enhanced photodegradation of methylene blue
Munawar Khalil⁎, Ervita S. Anggraeni, Tribidasari A. Ivandini, Emil Budianto Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Mathematics and Natural Sciences, University of Indonesia, 16424 Depok, West Java, Indonesia
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Crystal facet TiO2 Plasmonic resonance Photodegradation Methylene blue
A B S T R A C T
This article reports an investigation on the effect of crystal facet of TiO2 in nano Au-TiO2 heterostructures for enhanced photocatalytic degradation of organic dyes. Here, nano Au-TiO2 heterostructures with two distinct TiO2 morphologies, i.e. nanospindles and nanocubes, were successfully prepared and utilized for photodegradation of methylene blue (MB). Based on the photocatalytic experiments, it is found that TiO2 nanospindles exhibited superior photocatalytic performance than TiO2 nanocubes which primarily due to the exposure of (001) crystal facet. It is observed that the exposure of (001) crystal facet was able to increase the photocatalytic reaction rate by four folds. Additionally, integration with Au nanoparticles was also found to have a synergistic effect in photodegradation activity due to the presence of surface plasmon resonance (SPR) effect. According to the result, Au-TiO2 nanospindles was found to be most efficient catalyst for photocatalytic degradation of MB with pseudo-first order reaction rate of 0.1570min−1.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Rapid growth in human population has been widely considered as the main cause for several major water related environmental issues, particularly clean water scarcity. Advancement in industrialization has also further contributed to the severe water pollution problems. This mainly due to the irresponsible discharge of toxic substances into water bodies such as rivers, oceans or lakes without any sufficient treatments. In many developing countries, the majority of the pollutants in suburb water bodies comes from textiles, paper, plastic, leather or foodstuff industries which commonly in the form of toxic and carcinogenic dyebearing organic effluents [1,2]. As a result, this significantly reduces the penetration of sunlight transmission essential for photosynthesis and ultimately harms aquatic ecosystems and communities living in the vicinity of the water bodies [3]. Currently, various physicochemical wastewater treatment methods such as filtration, adsorption, coagulation or biological oxidation have been proposed in this regard [4–7]. Nevertheless, most of these methods are still unable to fully remove many pollutants which mainly due to their high thermal and chemical stabilities [1]. Typically, the aforementioned conventional methods are not able to completely break down the dye but rather transform it from one form to another. Therefore, more advanced wastewater treatment method that can completely remove pollutants such as synthetic organic dyes is still desired in order to solve these water pollution issues.
Recently, photodegradation approach has been attracting many attentions due to its ability to offer many advantages such as the ability to fully remove organic dyes and the utilization of inexpensive and nontoxic semiconducting materials as the heterogeneous catalyst. Among various types of semiconductor-based catalysts, titanium dioxide (TiO2) nanoparticles has widely been used due to its good photocatalytic activity, chemical stability, environmental friendliness and cost effectiveness. In general, photodegradation of dyes using semiconductors such as TiO2 is initiated by the absorption of light energy which is used to excite electrons in valence band to conduction band generating charge carriers, i.e. electron-hole pairs [1,8]. These charge carriers would then be used to transform water or dissolve oxygen molecules into highly reactive oxygen species (ROS) such as superoxide anion radical (•O2−), hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), hydroxyl radical (•OH), and singlet oxygen (1O2) which can react with organic pollutants and decompose them [9–11]. Nevertheless, the application of TiO2 for largescale industrial wastewater treatment is sometimes restricted by several limitations such as its large energy bandgap (~3.2 eV) and fast electronhole recombination [12,13]. Furthermore, the photocatalytic efficiency is also often reduced at highly concentrated dye solution primarily due to the low dye absorption and light absorption competition with dye [14,15].
In the last several years, tremendous efforts have been made to address the aforementioned shortcomings. For instance, integration of

TiO2 nanoparticles with photosensitizers has been widely used to broaden the light absorption spectrum into visible range. Currently, various types of photosensitizers, i.e. organic dyes, metal complexes, metal organic frameworks (MOF) or other semiconducting materials such as quantum dots, have successfully been used in many photocatalytic reactions [16–20]. Recently, plasmonic nanoparticles can also be used to further enhance photocatalytic activity of TiO2 due to the presence of surface plasmon resonance (SPR) effect [21–23]. It is reported that SPR is able to both facilitate the absorption of visible light and prevent the occurrence of fast electron-holes recombination [24–26]. Enhancement in photocatalytic activity can also be achieved by exposing specific TiO2 crystal facet [27–29]. Liu and co-workers found that (001) facets exhibited better photocatalytic activity and selectivity in removing azo dyes [30]. In another study, Chen and coworkers also reported that nano-sized ultrathin anatase TiO2 sheet with almost 100% exposure of (001) facets showed a superior performance in electrochemical energy storage [31]. Nevertheless, very few studies have been reported to evaluate the influence of TiO2 crystal facet in photocatalytic activity of TiO2-containing heterostructure materials. Therefore, the effect of crystal facet of TiO2 nanoparticles towards the photocatalytic activity of nano Au-TiO2 heterostructures was studied in this work. Here, two types of TiO2 nanoparticles with different surface morphologies, i.e. nanocubes and nanospindles were prepared and integrated to plasmonic Au nanoparticles to form nano Au-TiO2 heterostructures. The as-prepared nanocatalysts were then used to evaluate which facet has the most reactivity in facilitating photocatalytic degradation of methylene blue (MB), a thiazine dye, and their photodegradation effectivity was compared with the pristine TiO2. Besides, the kinetics of each photocatalytic degradation reaction using different type of nanocatalysts were also evaluated in this study.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text: Titanium(IV) isopropoxide (TTIP) (purity: 97%), hydrogen fluoride (HF) (purity:> 99%) isopropyl alcohol (IPA), diethylenetriamine (DETA), absolute ethanol were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and used for the synthesis of anatase TiO2 nanoparticles with different morphologies. Meanwhile, gold(III) chloride hydrate (HAuCl4.xH2O) (purity: 99.5%), sodium citrate, and hydroxylamine hydrochloride (NH2OH•HCl) (purity: 99.99%) were also obtained from Sigma-Aldrich and used as the reagent in the synthesis of Au nanoparticles. Furthermore, hydrochloric acid (HCl) (purchased from Sigma-Aldrich) was also used for the integration of Au and TiO2 nanoparticles. Finally, methylene blue (MB) was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and used in the photocatalytic degradation experiment.

sections.heading: 2.2. Synthesis of anatase TiO2 nanocubes
sections.text: In this work, anatase TiO2 nanocubes were prepared in accordance to the work reported by Sever and Unal (2015) [32]. In this method, 1.776mL of aqueous HF solution (40 wt%) was added dropwise into 5mL of TTIP while mildly stirred with magnetic stirrer. The solution was then transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave and reacted at 180 °C for 24 h. After the reaction, the mixture was then cooled to room temperature and the obtained precipitate was collected by centrifugation and washed several times with distilled water until the pH of the solution became neutral. The recovered white precipitates were then dried in a vacuum oven at 100 °C for 24 h and collected for further characterizations.

sections.heading: 2.3. Synthesis of anatase TiO2 nanospindles
sections.text:
A one-pot solvothermal method was used to synthesize anatase TiO2 nanospindles [33]. Typically, 30mL of IPA was firstly mixed with
1.00mL of deionized water using magnetic stirrer for 10min. 0.15mL of DETA was then slowly added into the solution and further stirred for another 10min. Into the mixture, 1.00mL of TTIP was then dropwise added while stirred for 30min. Then, the mixture was transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave and reacted at 180 °C for 24 h. The mixture was then cooled to room temperature and the white precipitate was then collected by centrifugation and washed with deionized water and ethanol, respectively. Finally, the obtained precipitates were then dried in a vacuum oven at 60 °C for 8 h then calcined at 450 °C for 2 h and collected for further investigations.

sections.heading: 2.4. Synthesis of Au nanoparticles
sections.text: To prepare Au nanoparticles, a seed-mediated method based on a study reported by Haiss and co-workers (2007) was used in this work [34]. Here, Au seed particles were firstly made by adding 125mL of 0.254mM of HAuCl4.xH2O into 12.5mL of 40mM sodium citrate solution while vigorously mixed using magnetic stirrer. The mixture was then heated at 90 °C for 15min and cooled to room temperature to obtain the final Au seed particles solution. To synthesize the final Au nanoparticles, 20 mL of the previously prepared Au seed particle solution was mixed with 180mL of deionized water, 7 mL of 2M NH2OH•HCl and additional 3mL of 10mM of HAuCl4.xH2O. The obtained final solution was then stored at 4 °C in dark and used in further characterizations.

sections.heading: 2.5. Preparation of nano Au-TiO2 heterostructures
sections.text: The integration of the as-prepared Au nanoparticles to TiO2 nanoparticles with different morphologies was carried out in acidic condition according to the work done by Zhang and co-workers (2016) [35]. Here, 0.1 g of each of the previously prepared TiO2 nanoparticles were added to the 50mL of the as-prepared Au nanoparticles solution. The mixture was then vigorously stirred with magnetic stirrer while the pH of the solution was adjusted to pH 3 by dropwise addition of 0.01M of HCl. Afterwards, the mixture was then centrifugated and the precipitate was collected by centrifugation. Furthermore, the obtained precipitate was then washed with deionized water and ethanol, respectively, before dried in a vacuum oven at 60 °C for overnight. Finally, the powder was collected and used for further investigations.

sections.heading: 2.6. Characterizations
sections.text: In this study, various characterization techniques were carried out to evaluate the physical and chemical properties of the as-prepared nanocatalysts. Here, X-ray diffraction (XRD) analyses was conducted to study the crystalline structure of the as-prepared nanocatalysts using PANanalytical X'Pert Pro MPD (PANanalytical B.V., Amelo, the Netherlands) with Cu-Kα radiation as the source and X'Celerator as the detector. The morphology, shape and size of the nanocatalysts were determined by collecting the micrographic images and conducting selected area electron diffraction (SAED) technique using TECNAI G2 Spirit Twin High-Resolution Transmission Electron Microscope (HRTEM). Additional micrographic analysis was also carried out using FEI Quanta 650 Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM). To study both optical and electronic properties of the nanocatalysts, UV–Visible (UV–Vis) analysis was carried out using Shimadzu UV-2450 spectrophotometer. Furthermore, the optical bandgap (Eg) of the nanocatalysts was determined by conducting the dynamic reflectance spectroscopy (DRS) analysis and estimated using Kubelka-Munk method (see Supplementary Data). Finally, the surface property analysis was also conducted to study Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area, BarretJoyner-Halenda (BJH) pore volume and BET N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm of the nanocatalysts using QUADRASOB evo (Quantachrome Instruments) equipped with FloVac Degasser.

sections.heading: 2.7. Photodegradation experiments
sections.text:
Photocatalytic activity of the as-prepared nanocatalysts was assessed by monitoring the degradation of MB (Fig. S1, Supplementary Data) in an aqueous solution under the irradiation of visible light. Typically, several amount of the as-prepared nanocatalysts was vigorously mixed with 10mL of 0.01mMMB solution with magnetic stirrer under the irradiation of visible light. Photodegradation of MB was performed with a 450W metal-halide lamp (Osram) for 60min. To study the degradation of the dye, an aliquot of sample was taken at various time intervals for the quantitative analysis of MB (see Supplementary Data). Degradation efficiency of MB by the nanocatalysts was then evaluated by calculating the percent of decolorization using the following equation:

sections.heading: 3.1. Preparation and characterization of the nanocatalysts
sections.text:
In this work, nano-sized Au-TiO2 heterostructure with two distinct TiO2 morphologies, i.e. nanocubes and nanospindles were prepared to study the effect of crystal facet exposure in their photocatalytic activity in photodegradation of MB. Fig. 1A presents both the XRD patterns of the as-prepared nanocatalysts. Based on the result, the diffractograms revealed that the reaction products from nanocubes and nanospindles syntheses can unambiguously be indexed as anatase since the observed Bragg's peaks for both reaction products are in good agreement with the literatures and no other TiO2 crystal phases such as rutile and brookite were observed [1,19,38]. Furthermore, similar XRD pattern was also observed for the corresponding nano Au-TiO2 heterostructures. This suggests that the integration of Au nanoparticles did not alter their crystal phase.
Additional evidence regarding the integration of Au and TiO2 nanoparticles could also be obtained from the spectroscopic absorption of the as-prepared nanocatalysts in the UV and visible range (Fig. 1B). Typically, TiO2 would strongly absorb in UV range near 400 nm due to the intrinsic electronic transition of TiO2 from valence band (VB) to conduction band (CB) [39]. However, integration of Au nanoparticles would render the nanostructures to show obvious absorption at visible range around 500–600 nm due to the surface plasmon resonance (SPR) phenomenon [40]. Based on the result, it is apparent that both Au-TiO2 samples exhibited SPR peak at 530 and 538 nm for nanospindles and nanocubes, respectively. This suggests that Au have been successfully integrated to TiO2 nanoparticles. In addition, it is also worth to note that the maximum wavelength due to SPR (λSPR) of Au-TiO2 was blueshifted from the original λSPR of the Au nanoparticles (545 nm) (Fig. S3, Supplementary Data).
Further investigation using SEM and TEM analyses was also carried out to study the formation and morphology of the as-prepared nanocatalysts (Fig. 2). Based on the result, it is apparent that both TiO2 nanocubes and nanospindles were successfully synthesized using hydrothermal method. Results show that reaction in the presence of HF resulted in cube shaped (Fig. 2a, c, and e), while reaction with DETA produced spindle-like nanostructures (Fig. 2b, d and f). From the low magnification TEM observation, it is also obvious that both nanostructures were well-faceted. In Fig. 2e, TiO2 nanocubes exhibits two sets of planes with lattice spacing at 0.352 nm which can be discerned as the (101) lattice plane for anatase [32,41,42]. In the other hand, co-facet with two coexist lattice spacings at 0.352 and 0.48 nm for (101) and (001), respectively, were observed for the TiO2 nanospindles (Fig. 2f) [33,43]. The exposure of this additional (001) crystal plane was also supported by FFT analysis where the (001) facet makes an angle of 68.3o with (101) facet (Fig. 2f, inset) [44,45]. Further analysis using selected area electron diffraction (SAED) has provided an additional evidence for the formation of anatase crystal phase for both reaction products (Fig. 2g–h). TEM result also exhibited that Au nanoparticles were successfully integrated on both TiO2 nanostructures. As shown in Fig. 2i–j, it is obvious that several spherical Au nanoparticles were attached on the surface of TiO2 nanocubes and nanospindles, respectively. Typically, Au could easily be recognized from TiO2 by comparing their contrast under electron microscope. TiO2 would generally appear brighter than Au since it has fewer electron density [46].
Surface area analysis was also carried out to determine the surface properties of the as-prepared nanocatalysts. Fig. 3 presents the BET N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and BJH pore size distribution (PSD) for all of the as-prepared nanocatalysts. Based on the result, both particles morphology and integration of Au nanoparticles did not substantially change the surface properties of TiO2. As shown in Fig. 3a, all the nanocatalysts exhibit a typical type IV with type II-like hysteresis loops (observed at P/P0 range of 0.6–0.9), indicating the presence of mesoporous features [47–49]. Nevertheless, PSD plot demonstrated that the large surface area of the as-prepared nanocatalysts are mainly deriving from the existence of both mesopores (2–50 nm) and macroporous (> 50 nm) features (Fig. 3b). It is worth to note that the presence of macroporous feature is more pronounce in nanospindles. It is believed that this unique multimodal porosity feature is desired since it allows not only the maximum interfacial contact with organic dyes but also facilitate better light absorption activity. Other surface properties such as the BET surface area and BJH pore volume were also presented in Table 1. Based on the result, it is clear that there was a significant increase in surface area as the particle morphology was changed from cube to spindle-like structure. Similar phenomenon was also observed for the pore volume. However, integration of TiO2 with Au nanoparticles was found to be responsible for the slight reduction in both surface area and pore volume. Such decrement is believed caused by the presence of Au nanoparticles blocking the pores on TiO2 crystal structures.
Additionally, estimation on band structures of the as-prepared
nanocatalysts also revealed that both particle morphology and integration of Au nanoparticle had very small effect on the overall bandgap energy of the TiO2 (Fig. S4, Supplementary Data). Unlike in doping approach where the bandgap energy of TiO2 is typically reduced, heterostructuring TiO2 with plasmonic photosensitizer such as Au nanoparticles has no significant effect in the overall Au-TiO2 heterostructures bandgap energy. According to result from Kubelka-Munk calculation, the as-prepared nanocatalysts had a very similar bandgap energy of 3.27 eV. Nevertheless, it is important to note that the integration of Au nanoparticles gives an additional light absorption activity at visible region, making them photoactive in both UV and visible regions.

sections.heading: 3.2. Evaluation of photocatalytic activity
sections.text:
Fig. 4 shows the photodegradation of MB using the as-prepared nanocatalysts. Based on the result, it is apparent that TiO2 nanospindles demonstrated a superior photodegradation ability towards MB in comparison to TiO2 nanocubes (Fig. 4a). The enhancement of this photocatalytic activity is believed primarily due to the presence of cofacets between (001) and (101) of TiO2 nanospindles. According to literature, TiO2 (001) crystal facet has been reported to have a better ability to adsorb and dissociate water to form ROS, such as hydroxyl radicals (•OH) and H2O2, which essential for photocatalytic degradation reactions [50]. Based on theoretical DFT analyses, this phenomenon could be attributed to the unsaturation in most of the titanium atoms which have pentacoordinated bonding configuration with oxygen atoms [38,51] (Fig. S5, Supplementary Data). Recently, Gao and coworkers also reported that (001) facet surface favors both the migration and separation of the photogenerated charge carries, therefore preventing a fast electron-holes recombination [27]. Furthermore, it is also worth to note that the enhancement in photocatalytic performance of TiO2 nanospindles may also be contributed from the influence of their large surface area (Table 1). Nevertheless, the photocatalytic activity increment due to surface area was found to be negligible compared to the effect of (001) facet exposure.
Further enhancement in the photodegradation efficiency was observed when plasmonic Au nanoparticles were integrated to the TiO2 nanoparticles. According to the result, while similar trend for the effect of crystal facet was still observed, the case seems valid for both type of TiO2 morphologies (Fig. 4a). Under the irradiation of visible light, the presence of Au nanoparticles significantly enhances the ability of TiO2 nanocubes and nanospindles to remove MB by almost two folds. Result
demonstrated that almost all of MB can readily be removed during the first 30min of photocatalytic reaction using Au-TiO2 nanospindles as the photocatalyst (Fig. 4b). The enhanced photodegradation activity of Au-TiO2 nanospindles can be attributed due to the presence of synergistic effect between the exposure of highly reactive (001) facet of TiO2 and the strong plasmonic properties from Au nanoparticles. It is believed that the plasmonic effect not only can help to restrict the electron-holes recombination but also facilitate the plasmon induced hot electron transfer from Au nanoparticles to TiO2 [12,52,53]. Furthermore, result from recycling was also proven that the activity of the as-prepared nanocatalyst remains nearly unchanged after 5 consecutive cycles (Fig. S6, Supplementary Data).

sections.heading: 3.3. Kinetics of the photocatalytic degradation
sections.text: Table 2 presents the apparent rate constant (kapp) for the photodegradation of MB using different type of the as-prepared nanocatalysts. Here, the value of kapp for each nanocatalysts were estimated by model fitting according to the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) model (Fig. S7, Supplementary Data). Based on the result, it is clear that the exposure of (001) facet in TiO2 nanospindles was able to significantly the reaction rate of the photodegradation reaction by four folds. Meanwhile, synergetic effect due to the presence of plasmon resonance effect was able to enhance the rate of photodegradation by two folds for both morphologies of TiO2 nanoparticles.

sections.heading: 3.4. Mechanisms of the photocatalytic degradation
sections.text:
Many reports have proven that the presence of photogenerated electrons and holes, or commonly known as charge carriers, play key important role in the photodegradation of various toxic organic dyes [1,2,54]. Upon light irradiation, photon with suitable amount of energy can readily excite electrons to conduction band (CB) of TiO2, while creating holes in its valence band (VB). These photogenerated electrons can then react with surface adsorbed O2 to form •O2−, which can degrade MB into small intermediates molecules and other by products such as CO2 and H2O. However, it is also believed that the degradation of MB can also be done by the reaction with another type of ROS, i.e. •OH, which can be obtained from (1) the reaction of holes and water molecules or (2) the reaction of electrons and H2O2 (produced form the reaction of •O2− and H+ which obtained as a byproduct from the former reaction). The evidence for the presence of these reactive species have widely reported in previous studies using electron spin resonance
(ESR) or other spectroscopic investigation using probing molecules [55,56]. In general, the overall possible reaction mechanism for the photodegradation of MB using TiO2 as catalyst can be expressed as follows:

The formation of these reactive species can also be rationalized by estimating the energy levels of the as-prepared TiO2 nanoparticles using
theoretical prediction introduced by Butler and Ginley, which can be expressed using the following relation [57,58]:
= − +E E X E0.5( )eCB g (13)
where ECB represent the estimated TiO2's CB potential and Ee represents the free electron energy vs. hydrogen (4.44 ± 0.02 eV). Meanwhile, X expresses the Sanderson electronegativity of TiO2 (5.8 eV) [59] and Eg is the bandgap energy. Since all of the as-prepared nanocatalysts showed a similar calculated Kubelka-Munk bandgap energy (3.27 eV), therefore the value of ECB was found to be 0.28 eV relative to standard hydrogen electrode (−0.28 V vs. NHE). Therefore, it is fairly possible for the photogenerated electrons at the TiO2's CB to reduce O2 to •O2− (Eq. (6)) since it has more negative reduction potential than Eo of O2/ •O2− (−0.18 V) [60]. In addition, the photogenerated holes could also facilitate water oxidation to from •OH (Eq. (7)) since the calculated VB of the as-prepared nanocatalyst was 2.99 V (Eo of •OH/H2O: 2.33 V). In addition, it is also reported that the removal of MB can also be occurred via direct photodegradation by light at the surface of the catalyst via Eq. (11) and (12) [1]. Moreover, the exposure of (001) facet increases
the population and lifetime of the photogenerated charge carriers. Thus, the formation of ROS was more prominent.
Integration of Au nanoparticles was also found to further enhance the activity of both TiO2 nanoparticles (Fig. 4a). According to kinetic study, the presence of Au nanoparticles was able to increase the apparent rate constant of the reaction by two folds (Table 2). Tremendous efforts have been carried out recently in order to understand the role and mechanism of plasmon resonance in photocatalytic enhancement of TiO2. Nevertheless, it is believed that the plasmon-induced resonance energy transfer cannot be the primary cause for the observed catalytic enhancement since the spectral overlap between TiO2 and Au is very minimum [61]. Besides, the catalytic enhancement due to the plasmonic heating cannot also be the major cause since most of the redox
reactions in Eqs. (5)–(12) require more thermal energy than the energy generated from plasmonic heating. It is then suggested that the most plausible mechanism for the plasmonic enhancement of photocatalytic in this study is via charge transfer and local electric field enhancement. In charge transfer mechanism, previous studies have suggested that the SPR process excites electrons in Au, which could then be transferred to the adjacent TiO2 conduction band [53]. These electrons migration has been investigated using femtosecond transient absorption spectroscopy with an IR probe suggesting that plasmon-induced electrons in Au can be directly injected into TiO2's CB via quantum tunneling [62]. Furthermore, the presence of SPR can also generate intense local electric fields creating “hot spot” regions near the surface of Au nanoparticles [63]. In this region, electromagnetic simulation study using the finite-
difference time-domain (FDTD) showed that the rate for the generation of electron-hole pair is 100 times higher than that of the incident electric field. As the result, the population of hot electrons that can be migrated to TiO2's CB is also increased, which are essential for photocatalytic reactions. Recently, Kamat and co-workers also reported that Au nanoparticles can also act as the storage for the photogenerated electrons in TiO2's CB preventing the fast charge recombination [64]. This is possible since the fermi level of gold is more positive (0.75 V) than TiO2 CB [65]. This storage electron effect can easily be noticed through the blue-shift of the surface plasmon frequency [66]. Based on the result, λSPR of Au-TiO2 nanostructures (530 and 538 for nanospindles and nanocubes, respectively) were blue-shifted from the original λSPR of the Au nanoparticles (545 nm). Overall, Fig. 5 presents the plausible proposed mechanism for the photodegradation of MB using the as-prepared nanocatalyst.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
The influence of crystal facet of TiO2 on the photocatalytic degradation of MB using nano Au-TiO2 heterostructures has been successfully studied in this work. Two types of anatase TiO2 nanoparticles with distinct morphologies, i.e. nanocubes and nanospindles have been prepared and used for the photodegradation of MB. Results demonstrated that the later catalyst exhibited a superior photocatalytic activity than the former due to the presence of co-facet feature where less stable but catalytically active (001) facets was obtained in addition to the more stable yet less reactive (101) facets. Photocatalytic experiments revealed that the exposure of (001) facet was able to significantly enhance the photodegradation reaction rate by four folds. It is believed that (001) facet surface favors both the migration and separation of the generated charge carries, which prevents the fast electron-hole recombination and ultimately leading to better efficiency in removing MB. Furthermore, synergistic effect was also observed from the
presence of plasmonic resonance effect of Au nanoparticles. Results showed that plasmonic effect was able to further improve the photocatalytic degradation reaction rate by two folds, both for nanocubes and nanospindles particles. Such synergistic effect is believed to occur not only due to the additional prevention of electron-holes recombination but also the plasmon induced hot electron transfer from Au nanoparticles to TiO2.

metadata.abstractText: This article reports an investigation on the effect of crystal facet of TiO2 in nano Au-TiO2 heterostructures for enhanced photocatalytic degradation of organic dyes. Here, nano Au-TiO2 heterostructures with two distinct TiO2 morphologies, i.e. nanospindles and nanocubes, were successfully prepared and utilized for photodegradation of methylene blue (MB). Based on the photocatalytic experiments, it is found that TiO2 nanospindles exhibited superior photocatalytic performance than TiO2 nanocubes which primarily due to the exposure of (001) crystal facet. It is observed that the exposure of (001) crystal facet was able to increase the photocatalytic reaction rate by four folds. Additionally, integration with Au nanoparticles was also found to have a synergistic effect in photodegradation activity due to the presence of surface plasmon resonance (SPR) effect. According to the result, Au-TiO2 nanospindles was found to be most efficient catalyst for photocatalytic degradation of MB with pseudo-first order reaction rate of 0.1570min.
